Posted By: davidhuman (5/3/2009 11:19:50 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Better than it first appears, since it can be used to make one of your opponent's prized artifacts a target for various shennanigans.
  
   
If you're desperate for offense, you could always animate something that isn't really doing much for you anymore. In a mono-colored deck, it could also provide a pinch hit defense from the likes of [Terror](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Terror).
  
   
Not amazing, but it has some creative uses. Any player from the old days will fondly remember this and [Aladdin's Lamp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Aladdin's Lamp) as being a prized combo ;)
  
   
2/5
posts.html:
Better than it first appears, since it can be used to make one of your opponent's prized artifacts a target for various shennanigans.

If you're desperate for offense, you could always animate something that isn't really doing much for you anymore. In a mono-colored deck, it could also provide a pinch hit defense from the likes of Terror.

Not amazing, but it has some creative uses. Any player from the old days will fondly remember this and Aladdin's Lamp as being a prized combo ;)

2/5

Posted By: No_Shoes (9/28/2010 8:12:15 AM)

posts.post_content:
**Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #2, 9/28/10**   
   
Just looking at this card brings back a whole bunch of memories; I started playing **Magic** during the *Revised* era.
  
   
Yes, the white border is ugly, and the washed-out printing of *Revised* cards stands out like a sore thumb. Yes, that template is hilarious by modern standards. No, this card is not worth four mana. No, Douglas Shuler cannot claim the same level of technical mastery that today’s crop of artists can. But this card--along with many of its brethren--is etched into my brain. It is one of the seeds that the tree that is my love of **Magic** grew out of.
  
   
Granted, most of its familiarity comes from opening it in countless boosters, sorting it into endless piles in the neverending quest to organize my collection, or flipping past it in boxes and binders looking for more awesome blue *Revised* uncommons like [Control Magic](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Control Magic), [Counterspell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Counterspell), or ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: Brusko651 (10/7/2010 7:41:23 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: [Animate Artifact](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Animate Artifact) can bring a whole new dimension to your deck, especially if you utilize artifacts with high mana costs. It's particularly powerful when combined with [Aladdin's Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Aladdin's Ring) or [Aladdin's Lamp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Aladdin's Lamp), but it can be even more effective when used on a mid-costed artifact like [Rod of Ruin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rod of Ruin), turning it into a 4/4 creature early in the game. Don't forget that Animate Artifact can also be played on your opponent's artifacts, which can be useful if you play with [Prodigal Sorcerer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Prodigal Sorcerer). It's a quick and easy way to get rid of your opponent's [Sol Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sol Ring) or [Ivory Tower](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ivory Tower).
posts.html:
Animate Artifact can bring a whole new dimension to your deck, especially if you utilize artifacts with high mana costs. It's particularly powerful when combined with Aladdin's Ring or Aladdin's Lamp, but it can be even more effective when used on a mid-costed artifact like Rod of Ruin, turning it into a 4/4 creature early in the game. Don't forget that Animate Artifact can also be played on your opponent's artifacts, which can be useful if you play with Prodigal Sorcerer. It's a quick and easy way to get rid of your opponent's Sol Ring or Ivory Tower.

posts.post_content: [Animate Artifact](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Animate Artifact) can bring a whole new dimension to your deck, especially if you utilize artifacts with high mana costs. It's particularly powerful when combined with [Aladdin's Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Aladdin's Ring) or [Aladdin's Lamp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Aladdin's Lamp), but it can be even more effective when used on a mid-costed artifact like [Rod of Ruin](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rod of Ruin), turning it into a 4/4 creature early in the game. Don't forget that Animate Artifact can also be played on your opponent's artifacts, which can be useful if you play with [Prodigal Sorcerer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Prodigal Sorcerer). It's a quick and easy way to get rid of your opponent's [Sol Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sol Ring) or [Ivory Tower](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ivory Tower).
posts.html:
Animate Artifact can bring a whole new dimension to your deck, especially if you utilize artifacts with high mana costs. It's particularly powerful when combined with Aladdin's Ring or Aladdin's Lamp, but it can be even more effective when used on a mid-costed artifact like Rod of Ruin, turning it into a 4/4 creature early in the game. Don't forget that Animate Artifact can also be played on your opponent's artifacts, which can be useful if you play with Prodigal Sorcerer. It's a quick and easy way to get rid of your opponent's Sol Ring or Ivory Tower.
